Sophie Ristelhueber's coronation at Paris Photo
subhead: Her work is lauded by international critics. Foreign collectors and museums covet her rare prints. Yet, at 76, the French photographer remains a discreet artist in her own country. For 40 years, she has been composing a demanding body of work, giving a new form to places marked by war or history. Honored this year with the prestigious Hasselblad Award, her work is on display at the Grand Palais during Paris Photo.

Trump demands Justice Department investigate links between Epstein and Clinton
subhead: Under mounting pressure following the recent release of a new trove of Epstein emails, Trump has ordered the investigation of former President Bill Clinton, as well as former Harvard president Larry Summers and banking giant JP Morgan Chase.

title: The relentless spiral of speed watching: 'If I don't set it to at least 1.5×, I get bored'
subhead: From TikTok to YouTube, more and more young people are watching videos at increased speeds to consume more content in less time.

title: Croatia qualify for 2026 World Cup as Netherlands edge closer and Germany stall
subhead: Croatia sealed their place at the 2026 World Cup with a shaky 3–1 win over the Faroe Islands on a night when the Netherlands all but secured qualification and Germany were pushed to the brink by Luxembourg.

title: Vantara, an Indian billionaire's enormous private zoo
subhead: An international report highlights numerous irregularities in the mass transfers of specimens to the private facility in Gujarat, India.

COP30: 'Those drawn to China's environmental push should keep a few facts in mind'
subhead: China is presenting itself as the leader in the renewable energy economy, positioning itself against the United States, which remains entrenched in fossil fuels. Yet, this transition has proven misleading, writes Pascal Riché in his column for Le Monde.

title: 'Delhi is no longer livable': Deadly pollution in Indian capital claims more than 17,000 lives each year
subhead: Millions of firecrackers set off during the Hindu festival of Diwali at the end of October have worsened the already extreme fine particle pollution engulfing the megacity. Every winter, Delhi's 30 million residents face a toxic nightmare, while blistering heat waves strike the city each summer.

title: Leaders of international Gen Z movement reflect on their countries' political futures
subhead: From Nepal to Madagascar and Peru, youth-led revolts driven by socio-economic demands have shaken governments. But their horizontal mobilization strategy, born of digital culture, now hampers the political outcomes of these movements.
